content:
This chunk is part of a Python function `draw_cube` which takes a center coordinate and length to draw a cube using lines in 3D space. The chunk specifically draws two opposite faces of the cube by moving to a starting vertex and then connecting it to adjacent vertices with lines, forming square faces on the cube.

lines.moveTo(center[0] + l, center[1] - l, center[2] + l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] + l, center[1] - l, center[2] - l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] - l, center[1] - l, center[2] - l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] - l, center[1] - l, center[2] + l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] + l, center[1] - l, center[2] + l)

    lines.moveTo(center[0] + l, center[1] + l, center[2] + l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] - l, center[1] + l, center[2] + l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] - l, center[1] - l, center[2] + l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] + l, center[1] - l, center[2] + l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] + l, center[1] + l, center[2] + l)

    lines.moveTo(center[0] + l, center[1] + l, center[2] - l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] - l, center[1] + l, center[2] - l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] - l, center[1] - l, center[2] - l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] + l, center[1] - l, center[2] - l)
    lines.drawTo(center[0] + l, center[1] + l, center[2] - l)
